Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Chit \Chit\ (ch[i^]t), n. [Cf. AS. c[=i][eth] shoot, sprig, from the same root as c[=i]nan to yawn. See {Chink} a cleft.] 1. The embryo or the growing bud of a plant; a shoot; a sprout; as, the chits of Indian corn or of potatoes. [1913 Webster]
2. A child or babe; as, a forward chit; also, a young, small, or insignificant person or animal. [1913 Webster]
A little chit of a woman. --Thackeray. [1913 Webster]
3. An excrescence on the body, as a wart. [Obs.] [1913 Webster]
4. A small tool used in cleaving laths. --Knight. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Chit \Chit\, Chitty \Chit"ty\, n. [Hind. chi[.t][.t][=i].] 1. A short letter or note; a written message or memorandum; a certificate given to a servant; a pass, or the like. [Webster 1913 Suppl.]
2. A signed voucher or memorandum of a small debt, as for food and drinks at a club. [India, China, etc.] [Webster 1913 Suppl.]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Chit \Chit\, v. i. To shoot out; to sprout. [1913 Webster]
I have known barley chit in seven hours after it had been thrown forth. --Mortimer. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Chit \Chit\, 3d pers. sing. of {Chide}. Chideth. [Obs.] --Chaucer. [1913 Webster]
chit n : the bill in a restaurant; "he asked the waiter for the check" [syn: {check}, {tab}]
